CAREER: Fundamental Studies of Cross-Kingdom Aggregate Biofilms for Energy-Efficient Wastewater Treatment

Wastewater treatment is becoming increasingly energy-intensive as treatment requirements become more stringent. A process known as Algal-Sludge Granule treatment uses larger particles which can be separated from the wastewater and, because of their size, settle more easily. The proposed process would occupy a smaller treatment footprint than many algae-based wastewater treatment systems and has the potential to be used as a bioenergy feedstock. The merits of this process make it compelling for adoption as a secondary treatment approach. However, this novel process is still in the early stages of development and much more knowledge is needed to understand the aggregation and function of these cross-kingdom granular biofilms. The PI will work with a teacher from the Clarke Schools for Hearing and Speech to build technical literacy in hearing-impaired students, using the highly visual components of Algal-Sludge Granules to teach concepts of mass-balance, environmental contamination and water and wastewater treatment. During the grant period as many as 60 undergraduates per year (300 total) could participate in new project-based learning and there is potential for more than 500 hearing-impaired students to gain exposure to environmental engineering curricula. 

This proposed research will demonstrate: 1) the mechanisms of initial granulation, 2) the structural integrity of different granule morphologies and how physical characteristics relate to performance and microbial ecology, and, 3) the resiliency of Algal-Sludge Granules under conditions of stress. Before the discovery of Algal-Sludge Granules, using granules cultivated with both microalgae and bacteria in treatment systems was unprecedented. Large granules of phototrophs and bacteria are rarely observed in the environment. This study is an investigation of the characteristic and performance of a unique microbiological system where eukaryotes and prokaryotes exist through symbioses. This fundamental investigation will improve the understanding of cross-kingdom microbial interactions in a biofilm aggregate but also provide valuable information to advance a promising treatment technology towards implementation. At the point of initial granulation, the coordination of bacteria and phototrophs, by correlating the expression of quorum-sensing signaling molecules and lecithin proteins with dissolved oxygen concentrations, will be studied. The physical characteristics of three common Algal-Sludge Granule phenotypes by observing granule morphologies and measuring their yield strength in response to physical stresses imposed by a nano-compression instrument will be documented. The relation of the physical characteristics to microbial ecology through DNA-based molecular techniques and performance of different Algal-Sludge Granule phenotypes in bench-scale reactors will be studied. The functional redundancy and diffusion resistance leads to Algal-Sludge Granule resiliency under conditions of stress by investigating chemical fluxes using liquid-ion exchange and amperometric microsensors and correlating any changes in treatment performance to shifts microbial ecology will be demonstrated. The resulting data will build knowledge that will help inoculate, operate and validate Algal-Sludge Granule treatment, advancing Algal-Sludge Granule process toward implementation. This study will also define the relationships between phototrophs and bacteria in the context of meeting wastewater objectives, which until now is largely unexplored.

por.por_cntn:
Meeting global sanitation and energy needs becomes ever more crucial as the world-population increases. In the U.S., wastewater treatment consumes approximately 75 billion kWh per year, or about 3% of our total energy use, with diffused aeration for activated sludge accounting for 25-60%. Recently, the symbiotic growth of oxygenic algae and bacteria have been investigated for organic waste and nitrogen removal. Unfortunately, algae generally do not bioflocculate sufficiently for effective separation of algae from water to efficiently harvest biomass. Oxygenic photogranules (OPGs), or granules containing layers of oxygenic cyanobacteria encasing a diversity of bacteria, hold potential for energy-efficient wastewater treatment. The oxygen produced by cyanobacteria support the aerobic degradation of wastewater COD and nitrification and the anaerobic interior of the granule has potential to support denitrification.

Intellectual Merit: To advance the science underlying this energy-efficient approach to treatment, this research improved the fundamental understanding of granule formation and the symbioses between the bacteria and phototrophic organisms within OPGs. Granulation is a repeatable phenomenon but not always predictable. This work solidified that filamentous cyanobacteria are critical to granule structure and that availability inorganic nitrogen needed in the successful formation of photogranules. Other physical and chemical parameters were correlated with OPG formation. Light and temperature optimization can enhanced reproducible granulation. Availability of divalent cations and total polysaccharides at that start of granulations can also influence the success of granule formation.

Not all granules are spherical. Investigations into the structural integrity and morphology of photogranules revealed differences in key strength and elasticity characteristics between granules of two dominant granule phenotypes: sphere and disk. Additionally, a unique dissolved oxygen model was created to understand the oxygen generation and consumption behavior for granules of different sizes. The model demonstrated that smaller granules follow substrate-limited behavior  and larger granules are diffusion limited. This outcome has significant implications in reactor design and operation. By exploring the ecology and performance of OPGs during granulation, different mature granule phenotypes, and oxygen transport and kinetic behavior, the results of this work offer useful data to inform the OPG processes and will advance the novel process towards implementation.

Broader Impacts: In addition to contributing new knowledge about OPGs and the commensalisms between phototrophs and bacteria to the field of environmental engineering, this study improved knowledge of biofilm treatment for undergraduate and graduate students. Biofilm systems are increasingly employed at wastewater treatment facilities but largely underrepresented in traditional environmental engineering curricula. I created and implemented new biofilm units in Introduction to Environmental Engineering and into graduate-level Environmental Microbiology and Environmental Biological Processes courses. This project also featured a collaboration with a math teacher from the Clarke Schools for Hearing and Speech to build technical literacy for hearing-impaired students using common core frameworks and Massachusetts state science standards to teach concepts of mass-balance, environmental contamination and water and wastewater treatment. During the grant period over 250 undergraduate and graduate students received instruction in biofilm treatment processes and hearing impaired students gained exposure to a novel environmental engineering curricula.
